text:
The writing samples sometimes don't indicate their true writing potential, because they are writing under someone else's direction.

I recently applied for a content marketing job and sent my samples in, and they were "meh" with the samples because I was under client editorial control. What they really liked were my personal blog posts that were written without external direction.

Try asking them for additional writing examples that showcase as many different writing styles as possible.

text: In hiring writers at Campfire Labs we always try to give test projects. I’ve found it’s a better way to see people’s talent than samples since it shows their draft, not their edited work.

text:
The thing that I look for most though isn’t necessarily the first draft, but how they respond to feedback. I usually send a one-pager with high level feedback (not line edits or comments in a doc). Then I see how much improvement their is between drafts.

One of our best writers delivered a bad first draft. But then he took my feedback and delivered something really good.

Conversely I’ve seen pretty good first drafts from people, given feedback, and then had them respond in a way that showed they weren’t really open to feedback. That was a much better indicator of their creative work style (and ego) than any sample or interview could have shown.

text: Honestly, I don’t think a single writing test is a good way to assess a full-time, in-house candidate. You say that the candidate’s samples didn’t “meet what you were looking for” ... how so? What I would do in this situation is ask for additional samples to try to allay that concern. “Can you show me something that’s a little more (friendly in tone / more deeply researched / less personal ) or whatever.
